To alleviate the difficulties often
encountered by students who desire
to borrow books on the reserve
shelves in the Hopkins Library,
Dr. John C. French advocates the
employment of the system used at
both the University of California
and the University of Chicago.
This system is the rental system.
Students under the plan, may borrow texts for as long as they desire at the nominal fee of three
cents per day.
The number of copies of texts
obtained by the library is determined by the demand for them for
use by students, it was explained.
At the Hopkins, the rental system would be advantageous, said
Dr. French, for those who desire
to procure certain books placed on
the reserve shelves by the instructors would not be forced to wait
until after 5 P. M. to obtain them.
In addition to the circulating
copies, there would be volumes
which could be used in the library
only, were the plan used here.

Dr. Joseph S. Ames, it was announced yesterday by Thomas F.

Chief among the provisions that
have been inserted into the constitution are the appointing of three
members of the alumni group to
the Board of Trustees and the
elimination of dues remittance as a
requisite for membership in the
former body.
Three to Be Named

At the first election, three members will be named for terms of
one, two and three years, respectively. At the expiration of each
term, the association will elect one
member from its body to serve
three years, no member being eligible for reelection within one year
after the conclusion of a previous
term.
Nomination, according to the
new constitution, must be made by
the council of the body and approved by a vote of the association.
Dues Not Required

All persons previously eligible to
become a member of the body tinder the revised document are still
eligible, but the payment of dues
is no longer a requisite. In addition
to every graduate of the Johns
Hopkins in the past and future
membership will include: (1) All
present or former members of the
faculty and of the Board of Trustees; (2) All present or former
Fellows by Courtesy and Research
Fellows; (3) All former students
of the graduate schools and all
former matriculates of the undergraduate schools.
Another innovation to be introduced is the appointment of a
full-time secretary. His duties, it is
said, will chiefly concern the
strengthening of the entire organization. It is expected that he will
travel to various cities to "promote
the collection of an alumni fund,
keep a directory of the alumni,
make recommendation to the council, direct the alumni office, cooperate with the president of the University and his secretary, or other
representatives, in the issuance of
bulletins to the alumni from departments of the University, and in
the organization of general and departmental gatherings of alumni at
the University, and shall in general foster and promote in every
way between the Alumni and the
University for the furtherance of
the objects of this association."
Board to Appoint

It is provided that the secretary
is to be appointed by the Board of
Trustees upon the nomination of
the Council of the Alumni Body.

New York, N. Y.—The Barnard
Bulletin, semi-weekly newspaper of
Barnard College, ceased publication
April 14, and was absorbed by Spectator.
The amlagamation of the women's
paper with that of Columbia College marks the first step in Spectator's program of expansion towards
its goal of a university paper. An increase in circulation of about one
thousand is anticipated by the campus daily.
Negotiations Lasted 3 Months

Only after considerable negotiations lasting over a period of three
months was the consummation made
possible. Authorities of both colleges authorized the consolidation,
Dean Virginia Gildersleeve of Barnard giving her consent prior to her
departure for Europe last week.
Miss Helen Block, editor of the
Bulletin, will be elected women's
editor of Spectator, a newly-created
position on this paper's staff, and
will be in charge of news emanating
from Barnard. A special section of
the issues of Tuesday and Friday,
the dates of the Bulletin's former
appearances, will be exclusively devoted to news of interest to the college women.
Poor Finances Cause

Financial difficulties attributable
to the prevailing economic depression motivated the Bulletin's request
for amalgamation. Miss Block emphasized the fact that it was only
with considerable reluctance that her
board agreed to the absorption, but
she said that its various members
realized the financial exigencies
made such a move imperative if
Barnard was to have any news medium.

men who are here to be educated
and not to have a good time.

New York, N. Y.—The Barnard
Bulletin, semi-weekly newspaper of
Barnard College, ceased publication
April 14, and was absorbed by Spectator.
The amlagamation of the women's
paper with that of Columbia College marks the first step in Spectator's program of expansion towards
its goal of a university paper. An increase in circulation of about one
thousand is anticipated by the campus daily.
Negotiations Lasted 3 Months

Only after considerable negotiations lasting over a period of three
months was the consummation made
possible. Authorities of both colleges authorized the consolidation,
Dean Virginia Gildersleeve of Barnard giving her consent prior to her
departure for Europe last week.
Miss Helen Block, editor of the
Bulletin, will be elected women's
editor of Spectator, a newly-created
position on this paper's staff, and
will be in charge of news emanating
from Barnard. A special section of
the issues of Tuesday and Friday,
the dates of the Bulletin's former
appearances, will be exclusively devoted to news of interest to the college women.
Poor Finances Cause

Financial difficulties attributable
to the prevailing economic depression motivated the Bulletin's request
for amalgamation. Miss Block emphasized the fact that it was only
with considerable reluctance that her
board agreed to the absorption, but
she said that its various members
realized the financial exigencies
made such a move imperative if
Barnard was to have any news medium.
